The Finals is the most innovative and fun first person shooter I've played since the release of Overwatch. It's fast-paced with satisfying movement & gunplay, offers an interesting twist on traditional team-shooter objectives, and has insane emergent gameplay potential with its fully destructible environments and instruments of chaos.

No live service game is ever going to please its entire player base with its priorities, balancing, and monetisation, but I think it's fair to say that Embark is one of the 'better ones'. They experiment regularly with limited time modes to keep the game fresh and different, with the most popular modes potentially becoming permanent. Their monetisation is arguably pro-consumer: no pay-to-win, no 'required' gambling (you can buy the items you want from the wheel if you get unlucky), a self-sustaining battle pass (you get enough multibucks to buy the next one if you complete most of it), free grinding for the premium currency, and no limited time availability for paid cosmetics. I am of the opinion that if Fortnite is the king of in-game emotes, The Finals is the king of skins. There's an insane range of fun, serious, and whacky ideas that you can mix & match to your hearts content, all without cringe crossovers.

As a casual player, I wish that Embark was more fast & loose with balancing, and made more of an effort to keep a wider amount of the available weapons/specialisations/gadgets viable, but I understand that's tough when you're trying to have a solid enough competitive scene to host your first major (which I am hyped to be there in-person for!).

I am still pretty new to gaming and I honestly was not expecting to get pulled into anything the way I did with THE FINALS. This was supposed to be a quick download to try and somehow it turned into one of those games where you blink and hours go by. It is fast, chaotic, funny, and it somehow makes total sense the moment you jump in.

One of the first things that grabbed me was how creative you can get with customization. The game does not take itself too seriously and I love that. You can build whatever version of yourself or the wild alter ego you have in your head. A huge femboy in thigh highs, done. A tiny guy in a unicorn tank top and a skirt, also done. The freedom to play with your look makes it feel like you walked into a neon carnival where anything can happen.

It also does not force you into those traditional hero style characters where everything is locked. You just pick a class, light, medium or heavy, and play the way you want. Light is quick with low health, medium is balanced, heavy is slow but so strong. Each one has its own weapons and gadgets and the specialties make them feel completely different. Switching classes actually changes the whole flow of the match.

The fairness surprised me the most. There is no pay to win mess. Everything costs the same and everything can be earned by playing. If you lose it is because someone outplayed you, not because they paid for some super item. The weapons all feel balanced too. Nothing works everywhere. You have to experiment and switch things up depending on the map and who you are fighting.

The destruction in this game is insane. You can tear down almost anything. Doors, walls, furniture, full buildings. And when something collapses it is real debris. Rubble falls, metal twists, and you can climb through it or use it as cover. It feels like the map is alive and reacting to every decision.

The creativity goes even further because the game rarely limits you outside of the map edges. Every match is like an open invitation to be ridiculous with your ideas. Blow a hole through a building just to drop a vault through the floor. Zipline through the air while throwing gadgets behind you like you are in an action movie. If you can imagine it you can probably do it.

And then there is the lore that shows up in the middle of all the chaos. Every match is set up like a giant televised game show with commentators who react to everything happening. They hype you up, call you out, and make everything feel bigger. Even the sponsors have stories. OZPUZE is an off the wall energy drink brand. HOLTOW is an insurance company for heaven because apparently that is a thing now. The whole world of the game has this fun personality behind it.

I did not expect to fall in love with a game this quickly but here we are. If you are new to gaming like me (hense the name ;) ) or you just want something fun and creative that keeps you locked in, THE FINALS is absolutely worth playing.

I want to preface my review with this: The Finals is one of the most fun and inventive shooters on the market right now. It takes everything I love about other shooters in its genre and runs with it, creating gameplay that is addictive, satisfying, and genuinely feels fresh and exciting.

That said, I can't recommend this game for a very specific reason. The use of AI and text-to-speech tools to replace artists and voice actors is genuinely incredibly disappointing.

If you weren't aware, I hate to be the person to break this to you, but both Scotty and June are generated voices using a language model trained on real voice actors. So are the player voices. And from what I understand, some designs such as sprays, stickers, and patterns on clothing are just straight-up AI-generated. 

I genuinely think this is unacceptable and we should demand better from developers and publishers. Everyone clowned on Call of Duty when they put AI art in Black Ops, and I don't see any reason this should be different. It's projects like this, and the success of projects like this, that is causing so much fear and uncertainty in artistic fields. What happens when a developer decides that music is too costly to compose, so they have a machine generate it for them? What about weapon designs, map layouts, or game modes?

This design philosophy is bad for creatives and bad for gamers because we don't get to experience the genuine human connection that comes with hearing a real human being behind the characters we enjoy.

I played this game nearly every day until a few weeks ago, when I learned about all this. I was excited for ARC Raiders, too, but haven't bought that game and won't until these AI-generated assets are removed. I haven't touched an Embark game since I learned about this. And you shouldn't either.

The Finals is a phenomenal game, that you shouldn't play because it shows devs and publishers that this is the kind of artistic nothingness that gamers will accept.
